name: niobium mine operation and beneficiation, from pyrochlore ore | barite | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/25051/documentation

This dataset refers to the production of 1 kg of (refined) pyrochlore concentrate (63% beneficiated), as a result of the mining and beneficiation activities in Araxa, Brazil. 

The activities start with the mining (open-pit mining) of the pyrochlore ore.

The activities end with the production of the refined pyrochlore concentrate, 63% beneficiated.

No allocation is applied.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are considered representative of current production practices.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The Araxa carbonatite complex in Brasil is located about 6 km south of the city of Araxa in the state of Minas Gerais and serves as the largest known niobium reserve in the world. Since the 1960s, the complex has been mined by CBMM (Companhia Brasileira de Metalurgia e Mineracao), being responsible today for more than 80% of the global niobium production.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Open-pit mining is applied and hydraulic excavators are used to extract the ore with different grades, which is transported to stockpiles awaiting homogenization through earth-moving equipment in order to attain the same concentration.;Conveyor belts (3.5 km) are utilized to transport the homogenized ore to the concentration unit.;Initially, the ore passes through a jaw crusher and moves to the ball mills, where the pyrochlore grains (1 mm average diameter) are reduced to diameters less than 0.104 mm. In the ball mills, recycled water is added in order to i) granulate the concentrate and ii) remove the gas from the sintering unit. The granulated ore undergoes i) magnetic separation, where magnetite is removed and is sold as a coproduct and ii) desliming in order to remove fractions smaller than 5μm by utilizing cyclones. Then the ore enters the flotation process - last stage of the beneficiation process – where the pyrochlore particles come into contact with flotation chemicals (hydrochloric & fluorosilic acid, triethylamene and lime), thereby removing the solid fractions and producing pyrochlore concentrate and barite as a coproduct which is also sold. The produced concentrate contains 55% Nb2O5 and 11% water and moves to the sintering unit, via tubes or is transported in bags while the separated and unused minerals enter the tailings dam.;In the sintering unit, the pyrochlore concentrate undergoes pelletizing, sintering, crushing and classification. These units not only accumulate the material but are also responsible for removing sulfur and water from the concentrate. Then the concentrate enters the dephosphorization unit, where phosphorus and lead are removed from the concentrate. The removal of sulphur and phosphorus have to be executed because of the local pyrochlore ore composition. Then the concentrate undergoes a carbothermic reduction by using charcoal and petroleum coke, producing a refined concentrate, 63% Nb2O5 and tailings with high lead content that are disposed in the tailings dam again.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: This dataset is based on the following publication: Dolganova, I., Bosch, F., Bach, V., Baitz, M., & Finkbeiner, M. (2020). Life cycle assessment of ferro niobium. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 25(3), 611-619. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01714-7. The original dataset reports the amounts per kg of produced ferroniobium. Based on information about the inputs & outputs of the mining and beneficiation subprocesses (reported on figure 2 and Table 3 of the abovementioned publication) and the inputs / outputs required for the the production of ferroniobium (inputs: iron oxide as scrap, aluminium powder, fluorspar, lime / outputs: slag removed from the tailings amount - check tailings comment) reported in Table 2 of the abovemetioned publication and assuming electricity production for the aluminothermic process equal to 0.475 kWh / kg of Ferroniobium (check electricity comment) the dataset has been disaggregated (after removing the inputs and outputs of the aluminothermic production process) and the values reported represent the production of 1.55 kg of refined pyrochlore concentrate (63% Nb2O5). As a result, all remaining inputs and outputs reported in the publication were dividied by 1.55 kg to correspond to the production of 1 kg of refined pyrochlore concentrate (63% Nb2O5). Particulate matter emissions were taken from the CEPMEIP database (see the respective exchange comments). CO emissions (fossil and non-fossil) are present due to the carbothermic reduction process taking place with petroleum coke and charcoal as fuels (Source: Albrecht, S., Cymorek, C. and Eckert, J. (2011). Niobium and Niobium Compounds. In Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, (Ed.). https://doi.org/10.1002/14356007.a17_251.pub2). Their calculation is based on the fact that the amount of (fossil and non-fossil) carbon emitted in the air, is the same with the carbon content of the CO emissions (see the respective CO emission comments). SO2 emissions were calculated based on the maximum amount allowed by law in Brazil (see the SO2 exchange comment). Despite the fact that in the original source the water is 100% recycled (13L as input and 13L as output) for this dataset the water input along with the amount of produced tailings are based on dry and wet mass balance. The presence of Particulates and SO2 as emissions is confirmed from the following source: Alves, A. R., & Coutinho, A. d. R. (2019). Life cycle assessment of niobium: A mining and production case study in Brazil. Minerals Engineering, 132, 275-283. doi:<https://doi.org/10.1016/j.mineng.2018.11.041>.

exchanges.description: This exchange represents the barite that is produced as byproduct during the beneficiation process in the flotation stage. The original value reported is 5.7 kg per kg of Ferroniobium produced and is taken from the following publication: Dolganova, I., Bosch, F., Bach, V., Baitz, M., & Finkbeiner, M. (2020). Life cycle assessment of ferro niobium. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 25(3), 611-619. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01714-7. After disaggregation of the reported LCI (see sampling procedure), the value has been adjusted in order to correspond to the production of 1 kg of refined concentrate (63% Nb2O5), based on the fact that 1.55 kg of refined concentrate is required for the production of 1 kg of FeNb.

flow.name: barite
flow.category: B:Mining and quarrying/07:Mining of metal ores/072:Mining of non-ferrous metal ores/0729:Mining of other non-ferrous metal ores

exchanges.description: This value was not originally present in the publication in which this dataset was based on (Dolganova, I., Bosch, F., Bach, V., Baitz, M., & Finkbeiner, M. (2020). Life cycle assessment of ferro niobium. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 25(3), 611-619. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01714-7). However, niobium mining is associaated with particulate emissions (Source: Alves, A. R., & Coutinho, A. d. R. (2019). Life cycle assessment of niobium: A mining and production case study in Brazil. Minerals Engineering, 132, 275-283. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.mineng.2018.11.041). The values for the PM emissions (PM2.5, PM10 and Total Suspended Particles, TSP) were taken from the CEPMEIP database. More specifically: PM2.5 = 5 g/t of ore , PM10 = 50 g/t of ore, TSP=101.72  g/t of ore. The amount of ore extracted for the production of 1 kg of pyrochlore concentrate, 63% Nb2O5 is 41.935 kg. Therefore, PM<2.5 = PM2.5 * 41.935.

flow.name: Particulate Matter, < 2.5 um
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: This value was not originally present in the publication in which this dataset was based on (Dolganova, I., Bosch, F., Bach, V., Baitz, M., & Finkbeiner, M. (2020). Life cycle assessment of ferro niobium. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 25(3), 611-619. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01714-7). It represents the land transformation. The value has been taken as a proxy from the tantalum chain from the following report: Classen et al (2009) Life Cycle inventories of metals, Part XI Tantalum powder, page 13 table 5.2. Land occupation: 7.85E-02 m2*a / t ore. Amount of ore extracted: 41.935 kg (referring to the production of 1 kg of pyrochlore concentrate).

exchanges.description:
This exchange is considered as a proxy for the produced tailings during the mining, beneficiation and carbothermic reduction activities. The original value is 54.9 kg and is taken from the following publication: Dolganova, I., Bosch, F., Bach, V., Baitz, M., & Finkbeiner, M. (2020). Life cycle assessment of ferro niobium. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 25(3), 611-619. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01714-7. 1.82 kg comes out of the aluminothermic processing (Source: Supporting information, Table S21, page 35 of this publication: Nuss, P., & Eckelman, M. J. (2014). Life Cycle Assessment of Metals: A Scientific Synthesis. PLOS ONE, 9(7), e101298. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0101298)
which is outside of the scope of this dataset and is therefore removed to represent the tailings production from the processes included in this dataset. Furthermore, the value has been adjusted to correspond to the production of1 kg of pyrochlore concentrate, 63% Nb2O5. Finally, this amount has been adjusted for dry and wet mass balance purposes.

Minerals Engineering, 132, 275-283. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.mineng.2018.11.041). More specifically: PM2.5 = 5 g/t of ore , PM10 = 50 g/t of ore, TSP=101.72  g/t of ore. The amount of ore extracted for the production of 1 kg of pyrochlore concentrate, 63 % Nb2O5 is 41.935 kg. exchanges.description: This exchange represents the gangue material extracted from the ground. Since 65 kg of pyrochlore ore is required for the production of1.55 kg pyrochlore concentrate (63% beneficiated), 41.935 kg are needed in order to produce 1 kg of pyrochlore concentrate (63% beneficiated)    (Source:Dolganova, I., Bosch, F., Bach, V., Baitz, M., & Finkbeiner, M. (2020). Life cycle assessment of ferro niobium. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 25(3), 611-619. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01714-7).  Gangue is calculated by subtracting the amount of Niobium extracted from the ground (0.73282) and the amount of iron extracted from ground (13.395 kg) from the amount of pyrochlore ore extracted from ground (41.935 kg).

Life cycle assessment of ferro niobium. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 25(3), 611-619. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01714-7. After disaggregation of the reported LCI (see sampling procedure), the value has been adjusted in order to correspond to the production of 1 kg of refined concentrate (63% Nb2O5), based on the fact that 1.55 kg of refined concentrate is required for the production of 1 kg of FeNb.

flow.name: Water

exchanges.description: This exchange represents the niobium metal extracted from the ground. Since 65 kg of pyrochlore ore is required for the production of 1.55 kg pyrochlore concentrate (63% beneficiated), 41.935 kg are needed in order to produce 1 kg of pyrochlore concentrate (63% beneficiated) (Source: Dolganova, I., Bosch, F., Bach, V., Baitz, M., & Finkbeiner, M. (2020). Life cycle assessment of ferro niobium. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 25(3), 611-619. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01714-7). Pyrochlore ore containes 2.5% of Niobium oxide (Nb2O5). (Source: Table 1 of the abovementioned publication). The subtotal masses of Nb2O5 is: Nb:69.9%, O:30.1%. The Niobium in ground is calculated by multiplying the amount of pyrochlore ore needed in order to produce 1 kg of pyrochlore concentrate (41.935 kg) with the Niobium oxide content (2.5%) and the subtotal mass of the Niobium oxide (69.9%).

flow.name: Niobium
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in ground

exchanges.description: Conveyor belt length is 3.5 km (Source: Dolganova, I., Bosch, F., Bach, V., Baitz, M., & Finkbeiner, M. (2020). Life cycle assessment of ferro niobium. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 25(3), 611-619. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01714-7) and is assumed to be in the facility for 50 years. Annual production of Ferroniobium in the CBMM facility is 68667000 kg. Based on the fact that 1.55 kg of pyrochlore concentrate is needed in order to produce 1 kg of Ferroniobium, the annual production of pyrochlore concentrate is 106433850 kg.

Life cycle assessment of ferro niobium. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 25(3), 611-619. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01714-7. After disaggregation of the reported LCI (see sampling procedure), the values have been summed and adjusted in order to correspond to the production of 1 kg of refined concentrate (63% Nb2O5), based on the fact that 1.55 kg of refined concentrate is required for the production of 1 kg of FeNb.

flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in water

exchanges.description: This value was not originally present in the publication in which this dataset was based on (Dolganova, I., Bosch, F., Bach, V., Baitz, M., & Finkbeiner, M. (2020). Life cycle assessment of ferro niobium. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 25(3), 611-619. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01714-7). However, the carbothermic reduction process is associaated with Carbon Monoxide emissions (Source: Albrecht, S., Cymorek, C. and Eckert, J. (2011). Niobium and Niobium Compounds. In Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, (Ed.). https://doi.org/10.1002/14356007.a17_251.pub2). Since the amount of non-fossil carbon contained in petroleum coke is emmited in the form of carbon monoxide, this exchange represents the direct (process) non-fossil carbon dioxide emissions as a result of the carbothermic reduction process. The calculation is based on the fact that the amount of non- fossil carbon in charcoal is the same with the amount of non-fossil carbon in the emissions.(See carbon content, non-fossil for CO and charcoal).

flow.name: Carbon monoxide, non-fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: This value was not originally present in the publication in which this dataset was based on (Dolganova, I., Bosch, F., Bach, V., Baitz, M., & Finkbeiner, M. (2020). Life cycle assessment of ferro niobium. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 25(3), 611-619. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01714-7). It represents the land occupation. The value has been taken as a proxy from the tantalum chain from the following report: Classen et al (2009) Life Cycle inventories of metals, Part XI Tantalum powder, page 13 table 5.2. Land occupation: 7.85E-02 m2*a / t ore. Amount of ore extracted: 41.935 kg (referring to the production of 1 kg of pyrochlore concentrate).

flow.name: Occupation, mineral extraction site
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/land

exchanges.description: This exchange represents the iron extracted from the ground. Since 65 kg of pyrochlore ore is required for the production of1.55 kg pyrochlore concentrate (63% beneficiated), 41.935 kg are needed in order to produce 1 kg of pyrochlore concentrate (63% beneficiated) (Source: Dolganova, I., Bosch, F., Bach, V., Baitz, M., & Finkbeiner, M. (2020). Life cycle assessment of ferro niobium. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 25(3), 611-619. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01714-7). Pyrochlore ore containes 27.57% of Fe2O3 and 17.50% Fe3O4. (Source: Table 1 of the abovementioned publication). The subtotal masses of Fe2O3 are: Fe:69.93% , O:30.06% while for the Fe3O4 are: Fe:72.36% , O:27.64%. First the iron content of the two iron oxides is calculated  by multiplying the amount of pyrochlore ore needed in order to produce 1 kg of pyrochlore concentrate (41.935 kg) with the Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 content in the ore and the subtotal mass of these iron oxides (69.93% and 72.36% respectively). The iron in ground is subsequently calculated by adding the calculated  iron contents of these oxides.

flow.name: Iron
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in ground

exchanges.description: The original value is 14.1 MJ and represents the amount of electricity required per 1 kg of produced ferroniobium (FeNb). This value taken from the followingValue taken from the following publication: Dolganova, I., Bosch, F., Bach, V., Baitz, M., & Finkbeiner, M. (2020). Life cycle assessment of ferro niobium. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 25(3), 611-619. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01714-7. The value was first converted to kWh and then the amount of electricity required for the aluminothermic reduction was removed to ensure that the electricity required corresponds to the production of 1 kg of refined concentrate (63% Nb2O5). The amount of electricity required for the aluminothermic processing is assumed to be 0.475 kWh (Source: http://heattreatconsortium.com/metals-advisor/electric-arc-furnace/electric-arc-furnace-energy-consumption/). Finally, the value from subtraction was divided by 1.55, since 1.55 kg of pyrochlore concentrate are required for the production of 1 kg of FeNb.

exchanges.description: Due to lack of data about the amount of SO2 released, the maximum amount that is allowed from the Brazilian law is taken into account (i.e 2000 g/mkcal) (million) (Source: http://www.braziliannr.com/brazilian-environmental-legislation/conama-resolution-8-90/). The energy required for the production of 1 kg of concentrate is : 13.542 MJ (2.258 from liquified petroleum gas, 3.0968 MJ from Diesel, 0.065 MJ from Kerosene, 0.129 MJ from Biodiesel and 7.99355 MJ from electricity - check comment on each indivual fuel on this dataset). This amount is converted to mkcal and and the maximum amount of SO2 released per kg of concentrate can be calculated.

flow.name: Sulfur dioxide
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: This exchange represents the total thermal energy produced from liquefied petroleum gas. The original value reported was 3.5 MJ per 1 kg of produced ferroniobium (FeNb). The abovementioned value is taken from the following publication: Dolganova, I., Bosch, F., Bach, V., Baitz, M., & Finkbeiner, M. (2020). Life cycle assessment of ferro niobium. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 25(3), 611-619. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01714-7. After disaggregation of the reported LCI (see sampling procedure), the value has been adjusted in order to correspond to the production of 1 kg of refined concentrate (63% Nb2O5), based on the fact that 1.55 kg of refined concentrate is required for the production of 1 kg of FeNb.

defaultProvider.category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/353:Steam and air conditioning supply/3530:Steam and air conditioning supply

exchanges.description: This value was not originally present in the publication in which this dataset was based on (Dolganova, I., Bosch, F., Bach, V., Baitz, M., & Finkbeiner, M. (2020). Life cycle assessment of ferro niobium. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 25(3), 611-619. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01714-7). However, the carbothermic reduction process is associaated with Carbon Monoxide emissions (Source: Albrecht, S., Cymorek, C. and Eckert, J. (2011). Niobium and Niobium Compounds. In Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, (Ed.). https://doi.org/10.1002/14356007.a17_251.pub2). Since the amount of fossil carbon contained in petroleum coke is emmited in the form of carbon monoxide, this exchange represents the direct (process) fossil carbon monoxide emissions as a result of the carbothermic reduction process. The calculation is based on the fact that the amount of fossil carbon in petroleum coke is the same with the amount of fossil carbon in the emissions.(See carbon content, fossil for CO and petroleum coke).

exchanges.description: This exchange represents the amount of overburden produced from the mining activities.The original value reported is 29.5 kg per 1 kg of produced ferroniobium (FeNb). The abovementioned value is taken from the following publication: Dolganova, I., Bosch, F., Bach, V., Baitz, M., & Finkbeiner, M. (2020). Life cycle assessment of ferro niobium. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 25(3), 611-619. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01714-7. After disaggregation of the reported LCI (see sampling procedure), the value has been adjusted in order to correspond to the production of 1 kg of refined concentrate (63% Nb2O5), based on the fact that 1.55 kg of refined concentrate is required for the production of 1 kg of FeNb.
